Ian Badcoe wrote:

>>...
>>
>>Thus I was thinking that a pool
>>of dead species (or a token genome from each, say the species champ)
>>could be kept and that we could implement some mechanism for avoiding
>>the area of the fitness space represented by these genomes - using the
>>genome compatibility function.
>>
>>...
>>    
>>
>
>We (you don't know who) considered this years ago as part of searching 
>protein folding configuration spaces (200+ dimensions) but we never tried it.
>
>Call it an "Enforced Exploration" phase.
>
>The idea was (this was in the context of steepest-descents or simulated 
>annealing) to introduce an artificial force that drove the system away from 
>one energy minimum (c.f. fitness peak).  We theorised that we would know 
>when we had driven the system far enough, if when we released it, it did 
>not fall back into the same optimum...
>
>Of course, you could then chase the new optimum as far as was constructive, 
>decide to drive away from it was well, and find you had got into a cycle 
>where you ended up back in the original one.
>
>BUT...
>
>What if we kept exemplars of previous successful species in a list such as 
>you were using for your TTT fitness assessments.  Then we could drive away 
>from all of them during the EE-phase...
>  
>
To limit CPU overhead we should try to keep this list as short as 
possible, on the other hand there may be scenarios where there are a lot 
of local optima and thus we need to track of all of them. One idea then 
is to keep adding local optima to the list as species die, but instead 
of arbitrarily removing items from the end of the list (after a number 
of gens or whatever) we thin out the list by removing local optima that 
aren't anywhere near any of the current population.

>The other take I considered on the same thing was to wonder whether one 
>could formulate a modification of the molecular energy function (c.f. 
>fitness function) that would specifically remove one minimum (peak) from 
>the landscape.  Obviously not in the general case but since we are 
>designing that function ourselves...
>  
>

I think this is what Greg was getting at. Right now I favour tracking 
the species threshold, e.g. if it was at least 30 for the whole lifetime 
of a species that died, then one can summise that there aren't any 
(easily found) good genomes within distance 30 of the center of that 
species(assuming the center didn't move too much). Therefore the easiest 
thing to do is to test all new genomes before evaluation proper, and if 
they are within range of a 'dead-spot' then just allocate them a zero 
(or very low) fitness without wasting time evaluating them fully.

This approach could generate 'volcanoes' within the fitness space, and 
new genomes will then tend to cluster on the rim of volcanoes. Of 
course, after time the species on the rim will die and form another 
'crater'. Eventually the whole area of the original peak will be one big 
crater and the search will drift off into other areas. This however may 
take some time especially if you consider that I would favour increasing 
the species drop-off age to ensure we had more fully explored an area 
before we declared it as a no-go zone. So perhaps measuring new genomes 
propensity to move back to the local optima would be a way of 
short-cutting this lengthy process, e.g. if the whole of the  new 
species is at distance 30.1 from teh old local optima then we can 
summise that they are on the edge of it's rim and that we should 
increase it's radius.

Colin.
